edu.bath.transitivityutils
Class Relations

  edu.bath.transitivityutils.Relations

Provides static utility methods for creating and working with Relation instances.

Method Detail

newTransitiveRelation

public static <E> TransitiveRelation<E> newTransitiveRelation()
Creates a new, empty, transitive relation.

The created TransitiveRelation is serializable, as long as the objects in the relation are themselves serializable.

newTransitiveBiRelation

public static <E> TransitiveBiRelation<E> newTransitiveBiRelation()
Creates a new, empty, bidirectional transitive relation.

The created TransitiveBiRelation is serializable, as long as the objects in the relation are themselves serializable.

merge

public static <E> void merge(TransitiveRelation<? super E> relation,
                             Navigator<E> navigator)
Merges into a TransitiveRelation all particular relationships found in the specified navigator. The relationships of the navigator are allowed to form a cycle (if it is known that the navigator is acyclic, then mergeAcyclic(TransitiveRelation, Navigator) is preferable).

The effects of this method are equivalent to invoking the code: 

for (E subject : navigator.domain()) {
            for (E object : navigator.related(subject)) {
                relation.relate(subject, object);
            }
        }

There is an important difference though: doing this work via this method typically results in much more memory-efficient representation of the relationships.

The relationships of a navigator are found by iterating its domain, and for each object in that, finding all objects related to it.

Parameters:
relation - the transitive relation into which to merge the relationships of the navigator
navigator - a navigator

mergeAcyclic

public static <E> void mergeAcyclic(TransitiveRelation<? super E> relation,
                                    Navigator<E> acyclicNavigator)
Merges into a TransitiveRelation all particular relationships found in the specified acyclic navigator. If the relationships of the navigator are found to form a cycle, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown. Navigators with cycles can be accommodated by the more general merge(TransitiveRelation, Navigator) method.

The effects of this method are equivalent to invoking the code: 

for (E subject : navigator.domain()) {
            for (E object : navigator.related(subject)) {
                relation.relate(subject, object);
            }
        }

There is an important difference though: doing this work via this method typically results in much more memory-efficient representation of the relationships.

The relationships of a navigator are found by iterating its domain, and for each object in that, finding all objects related to it.

Parameters:
relation - the transitive relation into which to merge the relationships of the navigator
acyclicNavigator - a navigator
